Cluster1-10.paragraph: 1. CTRL, or carboxyl-terminal esterase/lipase, is involved in lipid metabolism, particularly in the hydrolysis of triglycerides and cholesteryl esters. This activity is crucial for lipid digestion and the subsequent absorption and processing within cells.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("CTRL") AND ("lipid metabolism" OR "hydrolysis" OR "triglycerides") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 2. HSD17B14, a member of the hydroxysteroid (17-beta) dehydrogenase family, is implicated in steroid metabolism, where it may function in the inactivation of estradiol. Steroid hormones play a role in a wide array of physiological processes, including lipid metabolism and homeostasis.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("HSD17B14") AND ("steroid metabolism" OR "estradiol" OR "lipid metabolism") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Qureshi, Rehana, Picon-Ruiz, Manuel, Aurrekoetxea-Rodriguez, Iskander, Nunes de Paiva, Vanessa, D'Amico, Massimo, Yoon, Hyunho, Radhakrishnan, Ramya, Morata-Tarifa, Cynthia, Ince, Tan, Lippman, Marc E, Thaller, Seth R, Rodgers, Steven E, Kesmodel, Susan, Vivanco, Maria Del Mar, Slingerland, Joyce M. "The Major Pre- and Postmenopausal Estrogens Play Opposing Roles in Obesity-Driven Mammary Inflammation and Breast Cancer Development." Cell metabolism, 2020, pp. 1154-1172.e9, doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cmet.2020.05.008

Sivik, T, Vikingsson, S, Gréen, H, Jansson, A. "Expression patterns of 17β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase 14 in human tissues." Hormone and metabolic research = Hormon- und Stoffwechselforschung = Hormones et metabolisme, 2012, pp. 949-56, doi: https://doi.org/10.1055/s-0032-1321815

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 3. KIAA0232's function is not well characterized, but it is believed to be involved in intracellular transport mechanisms, which could indirectly affect lipid distribution and signaling within the cell.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("KIAA0232") AND ("intracellular transport" OR "lipid distribution" OR "signaling") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 4. PAQR8, part of the progestin and adipoQ receptor family, is involved in various cellular processes, including membrane receptor activity and possibly signaling pathways related to lipid metabolism.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("PAQR8") AND ("membrane receptor" OR "lipid metabolism" OR "signaling pathways") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Charles, Nathan J, Thomas, Peter, Lange, Carol A. "Expression of membrane progesterone receptors (mPR/PAQR) in ovarian cancer cells: implications for progesterone-induced signaling events." Hormones & cancer, 2010, pp. 167-76, doi: https://doi.org/10.1007/s12672-010-0023-9

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 5. PLA2G1B, or phospholipase A2, catalyzes the hydrolysis of glycerophospholipids to produce free fatty acids and lysophospholipids, which are important for membrane dynamics and the production of lipid mediators.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("PLA2G1B") AND ("phospholipase" OR "lipid mediators" OR "membrane dynamics") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Labonté, Eric D, Kirby, R Jason, Schildmeyer, Nicholas M, Cannon, April M, Huggins, Kevin W, Hui, David Y. "Group 1B phospholipase A2-mediated lysophospholipid absorption directly contributes to postprandial hyperglycemia." Cluster1-10.paragraph: 6. RNF145 is an E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase that is involved in the regulation of lipid metabolism, particularly in the degradation of enzymes involved in lipid biosynthesis.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("RNF145") AND ("lipid metabolism" OR "E3 ubiquitin ligase" OR "enzyme degradation") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Menzies, Sam A, Volkmar, Norbert, van den Boomen, Dick Jh, Timms, Richard T, Dickson, Anna S, Nathan, James A, Lehner, Paul J. Cluster1-10.paragraph: 7. SGMS1, sphingomyelin synthase 1, is involved in sphingolipid metabolism, catalyzing the formation of sphingomyelin from ceramide. Sphingolipids are essential components of cell membranes and play a role in signal transduction.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("SGMS1") AND ("sphingolipid metabolism" OR "signal transduction" OR "cell membranes") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 8. SLC7A8, a system L amino acid transporter, is involved in the transport of large neutral amino acids across the cell membrane. While not directly involved in lipid metabolism, amino acid transport can influence cellular growth and metabolism, which may indirectly affect lipid dynamics.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("SLC7A8") AND ("amino acid transport" OR "cellular growth" OR "lipid metabolism") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Gaccioli, Francesca, Aye, Irving L M H, Roos, Sara, Lager, Susanne, Ramirez, Vanessa I, Kanai, Yoshikatsu, Powell, Theresa L, Jansson, Thomas. "Expression and functional characterisation of System L amino acid transporters in the human term placenta." Cluster1-10.paragraph: 9. TBC1D12 is a member of the Tre-2/Bub2/Cdc16 (TBC) domain family and is implicated in intracellular trafficking. Its role may intersect with lipid membrane composition and signaling pathways.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("TBC1D12") AND ("intracellular trafficking" OR "TBC domain" OR "lipid membrane") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 10. TMCC1, transmembrane and coiled-coil domain family 1, is involved in the regulation of intracellular trafficking and membrane organization, which can influence lipid distribution and signaling.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("TMCC1") AND ("intracellular trafficking" OR "membrane organization" OR "lipid distribution") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 11. UBE2Q2, an E2 ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme, is involved in the ubiquitin-proteasome system, which can regulate the turnover of proteins involved in lipid metabolism.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("UBE2Q2") AND ("ubiquitin-proteasome" OR "lipid metabolism" OR "protein turnover") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Nikseresht, Mohsen, Seghatoleslam, Atefeh, Monabati, Ahmad, Talei, Abdolrassul, Ghalati, Farzaneh Bozorg, Owji, Ali Akbar. "Overexpression of the novel human gene, UBE2Q2, in breast cancer." Cancer genetics and cytogenetics, 2010, pp. 101-6, doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cancergencyto.2009.11.020

Cluster1-10.paragraph: 12. WDR47, a WD repeat-containing protein, is involved in vesicular trafficking, which is essential for the transport of lipids and other macromolecules within the cell.
Cluster1-10.keyword: ("WDR47") AND ("vesicular trafficking" OR "macromolecules" OR "lipids") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 1. LMF1 (Lipase Maturation Factor 1) is crucial for the proper folding and maturation of lipoprotein lipase (LPL) and hepatic lipase (HL), enzymes that are essential for lipid metabolism. LMF1 deficiency can lead to hypertriglyceridemia due to impaired lipase function.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("LMF1" OR "LPL" OR "LIPC") AND ("lipid metabolism" OR "lipase maturation" OR "hypertriglyceridemia") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Wu, Shuangcheng Alivia, Kersten, Sander, Qi, Ling. "Lipoprotein Lipase and Its Regulators: An Unfolding Story." Trends in endocrinology and metabolism: TEM, 2021, pp. 48-61, doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.tem.2020.11.005
Dron, Jacqueline S, Hegele, Robert A. "Genetics of Hypertriglyceridemia." Frontiers in endocrinology, 2020, pp. 455, doi: https://doi.org/10.3389/fendo.2020.00455
Alves, Mara, Laranjeira, Francisco, Correia-da-Silva, Georgina. "Understanding Hypertriglyceridemia: Integrating Genetic Insights." Genes, 2024, pp.  , doi: https://doi.org/10.3390/genes15020190

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 2. MFHAS1 (Malignant Fibrous Histiocytoma Amplified Sequence 1) is an oncogene with a role in macrophage activation and may be involved in lipid signaling pathways, although its precise biological function is not well characterized.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("MFHAS1") AND ("oncogene" OR "macrophage activation" OR "lipid signaling") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 3. MR1 (Major Histocompatibility Complex, Class I-Related) presents microbial vitamin B metabolites to mucosal-associated invariant T (MAIT) cells. While not directly involved in lipid metabolism, it is part of the immune response in the gut where nutrient absorption and metabolism occur.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("MR1") AND ("immune response" OR "MAIT cells" OR "microbial metabolites") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Godfrey, Dale I, Koay, Hui-Fern, McCluskey, James, Gherardin, Nicholas A. "The biology and functional importance of MAIT cells." Nature immunology, 2019, pp. 1110-1128, doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41590-019-0444-8

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 4. PLA2G1B (Phospholipase A2 Group IB) is an enzyme that hydrolyzes glycerophospholipids to produce free fatty acids and lysophospholipids, which are important for digestion and cell membrane maintenance.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("PLA2G1B") AND ("phospholipase" OR "digestion" OR "cell membrane") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 5. RASL11A (RAS Like, Family 11, Member A) is a small GTPase within the RAS superfamily, which is known to be involved in various cellular processes including growth, cytoskeletal organization, and potentially membrane trafficking.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("RASL11A") AND ("small GTPase" OR "cellular processes" OR "cytoskeletal organization") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 6. RNF145 (Ring Finger Protein 145) is an E3 ubiquitin-protein ligase that may be involved in the regulation of lipid metabolism through the ubiquitination of proteins involved in lipid biosynthesis and transport.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("RNF145") AND ("ubiquitination" OR "lipid metabolism" OR "E3 ligase") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 7. SLC2A6 (Solute Carrier Family 2, Member 6) is a facilitative glucose transporter, which may play a role in glucose sensing and homeostasis, although it is less characterized compared to other members of the GLUT family.

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 8. SNX25 (Sorting Nexin 25) is part of the sorting nexin family, which is involved in endosomal sorting and signaling. It may play a role in membrane trafficking and protein sorting within the cell.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("SNX25") AND ("endosomal sorting" OR "membrane trafficking" OR "protein sorting") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 9. SPIRE1 (Spire Type Actin Nucleation Factor 1) is involved in actin filament organization and is implicated in vesicle transport processes, which are essential for membrane trafficking and cellular logistics.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("SPIRE1") AND ("actin filament" OR "vesicle transport" OR "membrane trafficking") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 10. TTPAL (Tocopherol (Alpha) Transfer Protein-Like) is a protein with a potential role in the metabolism of vitamin E, an antioxidant that protects polyunsaturated fatty acids within membrane phospholipids.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("TTPAL") AND ("vitamin E metabolism" OR "antioxidant" OR "phospholipids") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]

Cluster1-11.paragraph: 11. USP38 (Ubiquitin Specific Peptidase 38) is a deubiquitinating enzyme that may regulate protein stability and function through the removal of ubiquitin, potentially influencing membrane protein trafficking.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("USP38") AND ("deubiquitinating" OR "protein stability" OR "membrane trafficking") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
references: Yang, Yongfeng, Yang, Chuanzhen, Li, Tingting, Yu, Shuyu, Gan, Tingting, Hu, Jiazhi, Cui, Jun, Zheng, Xiaofeng. Cluster1-11.paragraph: 12. ZYG11B (Zyg-11 Family Member B, Cell Cycle Regulator) is involved in cell cycle regulation and may indirectly affect lipid metabolism and membrane dynamics through the regulation of cell proliferation.
Cluster1-11.keyword: ("ZYG11B") AND ("cell cycle" OR "lipid metabolism" OR "membrane dynamics") AND (hasabstract[text]) AND humans[mh] NOT Retracted Publication[pt]
